coredata.dc:description: CdS demonstrate superior potential for H2 production, but exist deficiencies of low carrier separation efficiency and photostability limit their large-scale application. Hence, a novel Ag2S/CdS/Cd2SO4(OH)2 composite has been designed. In-depth measurements reveal that Cd2SO4(OH)2 will be in-situ reduced to Cd metal as an excellent electron trap and hydrogen production site during the photocatalytic process. As a result, photogenerated electrons and holes will directionally transfer to Cd metal and Ag2S respectively, leading to the separation of oxidation and reduction reaction sites. As expected, Ag2S/CdS/Cd2SO4(OH)2 and final Ag2S/CdS/Cd systems exhibit considerably promoted photocatalyst properties than many other CdS-based photocatalysts no matter on the illumination of UV, Vis or NIR light. The research not only provide a new insight to develop a low-cost, carrier spatial separation and full-spectrum-responsive photocatalytic hydrogen evolution system, but also displays a novel strategy for in-situ deposition of metal clusters on the photocatalyst surface during the photocatalytic process.

head.ce:title: In-situ-formed Cd and Ag2S decorated CdS photocatalyst with boosted charge carrier spatial separation for enhancing UV-vis-NIR photocatalytic hydrogen evolution

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: CdS demonstrate superior potential for H2 production, but exist deficiencies of low carrier separation efficiency and photostability limit their large-scale application. Hence, a novel Ag2S/CdS/Cd2SO4(OH)2 composite has been designed. In-depth measurements reveal that Cd2SO4(OH)2 will be in-situ reduced to Cd metal as an excellent electron trap and hydrogen production site during the photocatalytic process. As a result, photogenerated electrons and holes will directionally transfer to Cd metal and Ag2S respectively, leading to the separation of oxidation and reduction reaction sites. As expected, Ag2S/CdS/Cd2SO4(OH)2 and final Ag2S/CdS/Cd systems exhibit considerably promoted photocatalyst properties than many other CdS-based photocatalysts no matter on the illumination of UV, Vis or NIR light. The research not only provide a new insight to develop a low-cost, carrier spatial separation and full-spectrum-responsive photocatalytic hydrogen evolution system, but also displays a novel strategy for in-situ deposition of metal clusters on the photocatalyst surface during the photocatalytic process.

ce:section.ce:para: Solar-driven photocatalytic hydrogen (H2) production by water splitting has received great attentions due to the greatly promising and constructive strategies to convert renewable solar energy into clean chemical energy [1]. Among various photocatalysts, Cadmium sulï¬de (CdS) has been investigated as one of the most potential candidates for H2 evolution, owing to its appropriately positioned band structure, superior visible light response and easily controlled low-dimensional structures [2]. Even so, numerous studies have indicated that the rapid surface/bulk recombination of the photoinduced electron-hole pairs, which occurred within just 20 nanoseconds, will greatly prohibit the photocatalytic performances and practical applications of pristine CdS [3]. To overcome the obstacle of the ultrafast surface-charge recombination and further improve the photocatalytic capacity of CdS, a plenty of approaches have been addressed, among which probably the most resultful strategies being the compositing of CdS with some noble metal cocatalysts, such as Pd [4], Pt [5] and Au [6]. In this case, the generated Schottky junction heterostructures will facilitate the migration of charge carriers and suppress the charge recombination on the surface of CdS, as well as provide abundant reactive sites for photocatalytic hydrogen production. However, on account of the scarcity and high cost, the large-scale application of these noble metal-modified CdS photocatalysts has been severely restricted. Recently, some low-cost conductive supports such as layered transition-metal dichalcogenides (MoS2 [7] and WS2 [8]) and carbon materials (rGO [9], carbon nanotube [10], carbon dots [11] and so on) have been composited with CdS in an affordable and scalable manner. As a result, these modifications not only provide more active sites to promote the photocatalytic reaction, but also suppress the recombination of photoinduced electron-hole pairs on the surface [12]. Nevertheless, the imperfect structure of most dichalcogenides and carbon supports results in the poor electrical conductivity (â 5â10 000 S*mâ1), which is unsatisfactory for the efficient charge carrier transportation. As a nonnoble metal with great electrical conductivity (1.46 Ã 107 S*mâ1), Cd metal attracts more attentions in the construction of an efficient composite photocatalyst with CdS during these years [13]. Liu et al. have designed a series of Cd/CdS nanorods via a two-step in-situ chemical reduction method on the basis of a heat treatment process. In this process, the interfacial coupling between Cd metal and CdS has been built, which greatly promotes the surface charge transfer and further optimizes the hydrogen production performance of pristine CdS [14]. Zhong et al. have developed a novel post-treatment technology based on pulsed laser irradiation to construct a CdS/Cd Schottky junction photocatalyst, which exhibits 40-times enhancement of photocatalytic hydrogen evolution than pure CdS [3]. Although these relevant researches can not be industrialized, they give an inspiration that it is important to achieve the continuity of crystalline structures in the metal-semiconductor interface, which is crucial to accelerate the charge carriers transfer on the surface of CdS.

Meanwhile, it is generally difficult to realize highly efficient photocatalytic activity on a single-component photocatalyst because of the low charge separation efficiency in bulk. Constructing heterojunction structure has been demonstrated as an effective way to suppress the charge recombination in bulk and promote the photocatalytic property. Recently, Zhang et al. have prepared a CdS/Co9S8 Z-scheme heterostructure with effectively enhanced light-harvesting and charge separation capacities, and the synergistic effect between CdS and Co9S8 promotes the massive improvement of the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution efficiency [15]. Besides that, various CdS-based type-II heterostructure photocatalysts (CdS/ZnO [16], CdS/TiO2 [17], CdS/C3N4 [18] and so on) also show reinforced photocurrent density, promoted incident photon-to-electron conversion efficiency (IPCE) and high photocatalytic activities, indicating the superior photogenerated charges separation in bulk driven by the efficient heterojunction structure [19]. Even so, the low-usage of sunlight, especially the NIR light (â¼50 % in sun light), still restricts the practical application of CdS in solar-driven hydrogen evolution processes [20]. In response, two methods have been proposed to extend the solar-light utilization region of CdS from UV/Vis to NIR: a) Modification of CdS with up-conversion materials (e.g., NaYF4: Yb, Tm/CdS [21], NaYF4: Yb, Er/Au/CdS [22]). b) Deposition of noble-metal with local surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) effect onto CdS (e.g., Au/CdS [23], Black PhosphorusâAuâCdS [24], Au-Pt-CdS [25]). However, low NIR to UV/Vis conversion efficiency of up-conversion materials and the narrow absorption range (808 nm or 980 nm), as well as the high-cost of the noble metals still prevent the full use of solar energy and suppress the practical exploration. Fortunately, some experimental researches in our group have proven that constructing some narrow-band-gap semiconductors on traditional UV/Vis-excited photocatalyst is a win-win approach to extend the light absorption region and improve the charge separation efficiency simultaneously. As an example, our previous work has demonstrated the pivotal role of Ag2S in the RGO/Ag2S/TiO2 heterostructure photocatalyst, which not only extends the photo-responsive region to entire sunlight spectrum, but also boosts the charge separation inside TiO2 [19]. Similarly, Tian et al. have synthesized Ag2S/Ag3PO4 photocatalyst with clear core/shell structures, which shows superior photocatalytic performance towards the degradation of MO no matter on the illumination of Vis or NIR light [26]. It is observed that Ag2S has attracted great attentions as a promising photosensitizer for the photocatalysis by virtue of its narrow band gap [27]. Consequently, it is believed that coupling CdS with Ag2S could be an absolutely good choice to realize the highly efficient photocatalytic performances under full-spectrum sunlight irradiation.

Inspired by the above analysis, Ag2S/CdS/Cd2SO4(OH)2 composites (denoted as ACC composites) have been designed and synthesized by the one-step solvothermal strategy combined with an effortless in-suit ion exchange process (Fig. 1 a). It is found that the Cd2SO4(OH)2 could gradually convert into metal Cd on the surface of CdS microsphere under light illumination, where the metal Cd acts as an effective electron trap to prevent the recombination of electron-hole pairs on the CdS surface. Meanwhile, the introduction of Ag2S enables the absorption edge of pristine CdS will be extended to infrared region, as well as promotes the photocatalytic efficiency dramatically under varieties of light irradiation. Finally, the possible mechanism for the improved photocatalytic ability of Ag2S/CdS/Cd2SO4(OH)2 and Ag2S/CdS/Cd systems have been thoroughly discussed.

To synthesize Cd2(OH)2SO4 particle, 0.003 mol 3CdSO4Â·8H2O and 0.01 mol NaOH were separately dissolved into 20 mL distilled water, and then the NaOH solution is added dropwise into the CdSO4 solution under magnetic stirring. Subsequently, the obtained suspensions were poured into a 50 mL hydrothermal kettle and heated it to 200 â for 24 h. Finally, the pure Cd2(OH)2SO4 particle was obtained by centrifugation and rinsed 3 times with distilled water and ethanol at 15,000 r/min and dried at 60 â for several hours.

To synthesize CdS/Cd2SO4(OH)2 microsphere (denoted as CC microsphere), 0.02 mol Cd(NO3)2Â·4H2O was dissolved into 80 mL distilled water, and then 0.02 mol thiourea solution was added dropwise into the above solution under magnetic stirring. Subsequently, the obtained suspensions were poured into a 100 mL hydrothermal kettle and heated it to 150 â for 24 h. Finally, the CdS/Cd2SO4(OH)2 microsphere was obtained by centrifugation and rinsed 3 times with distilled water and ethanol at 15,000 r/min and dried at 60 â for several hours. For comparison, the pure CdS is prepared with a molar ratio of thiourea to Cd(NO3)2Â·4H2O of 2:1 in the same process.

To synthesize Ag2S/CdS/Cd2SO4(OH)2 composites, 0.001 mol AgNO3 and 100 mg CdS/Cd2SO4(OH)2 microsphere were separately dissolved into 10 mL and 50 mL of triethylene glycol (TEG), and then different amounts of AgNO3 were added dropwise to the CC solution to obtain mass percentages of 2 wt%, 5 wt%, 7 wt%, 10 wt%, 20 wt% crude product (denoted as 2ACC, 5ACC, 7ACC, 10ACC and 20ACC composite), respectively. Finally, the Ag2S/CdS/Cd2SO4(OH)2 composites were obtained by centrifugation and rinsed 3 times with distilled water and ethanol at 15,000 r/min and dried at 60 â for several hours. For comparison, the pure Ag2S were synthesized under the same condition.

The powder XRD patterns were drawn on a Bruker D2 PHASER diffract meter with Cu K radiation (Î» = 1.5406 Ã ) in the range (2Î¸) from 10 Â° to 80 Â°. The morphologies and elemental chemical distributions were measured by FESEM (30 S-4800 N, Hitachi) and HRTEM (Tecnai G2 F30, FEI Company). XPS and UPS measurements were executed on a PHI-5702 spectroscopy instrument with a monochromated Al Ka irradiation. The absorption spectra (UVâvis-NIR) were recorded by a PerkinElmer Lambda 950 spectrometer with wavelengths in the range from 200 to 2000 nm with BaSO4 as a reference. The specific surface area was obtained by BET measurement (ASAP 2020 M, Micromeritics). photocurrent density measurements were measured on a Corrtest CS 310 electrochemical workstation using a usual three-electrode system with a work electrode (series of samples coated FTO), a reference electrode (Ag/AgCl (saturated KCl)) and a counter electrode (platinum foil). The electrolyte was 0.1 mol/L Na2SO4 aqueous solution and the light source was a 300 W Xe lamp with different filters (detailed light source information to see Fig. S1 and Table S1).

The experiments of photocatalytic H2 generation were carried out in an automatic gas cycle photocatalytic hydrogen evolution system (CEL-SPH2N-D9) at vacuum pressure and constant temperature (6â). In a typical photocatalytic H2 production process, 25 mg photocatalysts are dispersed by sonication into 50 ml aqueous solution containing 0.1 mol/L Na2SO3 and 0.3 mol/L Na2S as sacrificial reagents (the pH of the reaction solution is 13.6, the reactor is a cylindrical glass instrument with a height of 11.5 cm and a diameter of 5.0 cm) with a stationary temperature at 6â. The suspension is then entirely vacuumized and irradiated under variety of light using a 300 W Xe lamp with different filters (detailed light source information to see Table S1). Finally, the amount of liberated H2 is obtained by the gas chromatography (GC7920, TCD, N2 as a carrier gas). In the same photocatalytic hydrogen production system, the Hydrogen evolution rate (HER) of photocatalysts under simulated sunlight was measured to obtain the Solar to hydrogen (STH) efficiency of photocatalysts, and the STH was estimated as follow:

In a similar process, 15 mg of photocatalyst was ultrasonically dispersed into 30 mL aqueous solution containing 0.1 mol / L Na2SO3 and 0.3 mol / L Na2S as sacrificial reagent (pH of reaction solution was 13.6) at room temperature. Before illumination (detailed light source information to see Tables S1 and S2), the suspension in the quartz glass tube was filled with nitrogen until the dissolved oxygen in the suspension was completely discharged. XRD and SEM are employed to detect the phase composition, morphology and elemental chemical distribution of the obtained samples, as indicated in Fig. 1b-i. Typically, for the pure CdS and Cd2SO4(OH)2 sample, all diffraction peaks can be lightly indexed to cubic phase of CdS (JCPDS 14-0688) and tetragonal phase of Cd2SO4(OH)2 (JCPDS 25â0106), respectively. As for CdS/Cd2SO4(OH)2 composite (denoted as CC composite), the co-existence of CdS and Cd2SO4(OH)2 could be observed directly, demonstrating the effective combination of two phases during the solvothermal process. Moreover, compared with CC composite, all ACC composites exhibit three extra diffraction peaks at 34.4 Â°, 36.8 Â° and 37.7 Â°, which are attributed to the (
1 Â¯
21), (121) and (
1 Â¯
03) facets of monoclinic Ag2S (JCPDS 14â0072), and no other characteristic peaks could be checked, demonstrating the successful introduction of Ag2S into CC composite and the high-purity of ACC composites (Fig. S2a). Notably, as show in Fig. S2b, with the increase of the Ag2S amount, the diffraction peak intensity of CdS decreases distinctly, while that of Cd2SO4(OH)2 remain unchanged, attributing to the selective reaction between Ag+ and Cd2+ inside CdS lattice (Eq. (3)). In order to clarify this phenomenon, the XRD spectra of CdS and Cd2SO4(OH)2 after react with Ag+ are performed respectively (Fig. S2c-e). It can be seen from Fig. S2c that CdS solution turns black rapidly after dropping AgNO3 solution, while Cd2SO4(OH)2 solution remains unchanged. Furthermore, the XRD results show that the used Cd2SO4(OH)2 has no other diffraction peaks compared with the fresh Cd2SO4(OH)2. Meanwhile, compared to fresh CdS, the used CdS sample exhibits lower CdS diffraction peaks intensity along with the generated Ag2S characteristic peaks. Therefore, it can be concluded that Ag+ will not react with Cd2SO4(OH)2, but has obvious ion-exchange reaction with CdS, owing to the significant solubility-product constant (Ksp) difference between Ag2S (Ksp = 6.6 Ã 10â50) and CdS (Ksp = 1.4 Ã 10â29) [26,28].

It can be seen from Fig. S3a that the pristine CdS particles are flower-like microspheres with diameters of 0.5â2 Î¼m while the pure Cd2SO4(OH)2 shows granular particles with side length of 5â15 Î¼m (Fig. S3b). As stated before, the combination of Cd2SO4(OH)2 and CdS could be accomplished via the one-step solvothermal method. Indeed, as described in Fig. 1c, the introduction of Cd2SO4(OH)2 into CdS has nearly no effect on the basic crystal structure, and the obtained CC composites also exhibit flower-like morphologies similar to the CdS particles. Additionally, it is reported that the solvent with low polarity and high viscosity will retard the nucleation process and further promote the formation of favorable interfaces during the ion-exchange process [29]. In this situation, Ag2S nanoparticles have been deposited on the CC microsphere surface dispersedly with triethylene glycol (TEG) as the ion-exchange solvent (Figs. 1d and e and S3d-f), and the formation of I ntimate interface between CdS and Ag2S will expedite the mobility of internal photoinduced carriers. However, as displayed in Fig. S3 gâh, Ag2S particles have gradually agglomerated into large particles and covered on the CC microsphere surface as more Ag+ (10 wt.%, 20 wt.%) are introduced, which will reduce the photocatalytic activity sites on the surface of CC microspheres and further restrict the photocatalytic activity of the CC composites greatly [30]. Meanwhile, in order to detect the element composition of 7ACC heterostructure and prove the favorable combination between Ag2S and CC composite, elemental mapping analysis and HRTEM images have been employed. Obviously, as show in Fig. 1fâi, the equidistribution of Cd, S, O and Ag elements indicates that Ag2S has been uniformly compounded on the surface of CC microspheres. The HRTEM image (Fig. S3i) of the selected region (Fig. S3j) shows that the measured lattice spacing for the crystalline plane can be assigned to the (220) plane of CdS, the (330) plane of Cd2SO4(OH)2 and the (110) and (
1 Â¯
11) planes of Ag2S, respectively. The above research can prove that the effective formation of heterojunction among Ag2S, CdS and Cd2SO4(OH)2, which is expected to greatly accelerate the transfer of charge carriers migration and play an excellent synergistic role in photocatalytic reactions.

The chemical composition and chemical state of the obtained photocatalysts are detected by XPS, as indicated in Fig. 2 . As expected, the survey XPS spectrum of 7ACC composite comprises all characteristic peaks of CdS, Cd2SO4(OH)2 and Ag2S composite, depicting the co-existence of Cd, Ag, S, O elements in the Ag2S/CdS/Cd2SO4(OH)2 composites and no other impurities could be detected (Fig. 2a), which is great consistent with the results of the XRD and EDX mapping analyses. Simultaneously, the high-resolution XPS analyzation for Cd, Ag and S have been carried out to detect their exact electronic structure and the valence state. Fig. 2b shows the details of the Ag 3d XPS spectra in pure Ag2S and 7ACC. Clearly, the peaks present at 367.6 eV and 373.6 eV of 7ACC composite are closely corresponding to Ag 3d5/2 and Ag 3d3/2 peaks of Ag+ in Ag2S [31]. As shown in Fig. 2c, the double peaks at 404.9 eV and 411.7 eV in bare CdS could be assigned to the Cd 3d5/2 and Cd 3d3/2 of Cd-S bond, respectively [32]. Interestingly, besides the above two major peaks, another doublet at binding energies of 405.2 eV and 412.0 eV could be observed in Cd2SO4(OH)2, CC composite, corresponding to the Cd 3d5/2 and Cd 3d3/2 of Cd atom belonging to the CdOH bond in the lattice of Cd2SO4(OH)2 [33], and the discovery of these two doublets obviously evidences the co-existence of two chemical environments for Cd atoms in the obtained composites. In addition, both of CdS and Cd2SO4(OH)2 exhibit two typical peaks at 161.2 eV and 162.3 eV (Fig. 2d), corresponding to the S2â in the lattice of CdS and Cd2SO4(OH)2 [34]. It is noteworthy that after the composition of CdS and Cd2SO4(OH)2, a new set of characteristic peaks at 162.1 eV and 163.4 eV exhibited gradually in CC composite and 7ACC composite, which can be induced by the generation of SS bonding during the combination process, suggesting a strong interaction between CdS and Cd2SO4(OH)2 inside CC composite [35]. Moreover, all signals of Cd 3d, Ag 3d and S 2p in 7ACC composite further shift for about 0.1 eV to higher binding energy compared with that in bare CdS, Cd2SO4(OH)2 and Ag2S, indicating the electron density change and surface reconstruction process via the intense interaction effect among CdS, Cd2SO4(OH)2 and Ag2S [36]. These phenomena further confirm the formation of the Ag2S/CdS/Cd2SO4(OH)2 heterostructure, which builds a charge transfer bridge to accelerate the operation of cooperative effect during the photocatalytic reactions.

As we know, the optical property of photocatalyst acts a pivotal part in photocatalytic performance. Fig. 2e shows the UV (200â420 nm)âVis (420â780 nm)-NIR (780â2000 nm) absorption spectra of the obtained samples. Pure CdS reveals an intense absorption capacity in both UVâvis light regions (over 500 nm), while the pure Cd2SO4(OH)2 only exhibits response in the UV light region (less than 300 nm). Clearly, after the combination of CdS with Cd2SO4(OH)2, the UV and Vis light responses of the CC composite are remarkably improved compared with that of Cd2SO4(OH)2 sample. Furthermore, benefiting from the narrow band gap energy of 0.95 eV, Ag2S displays abroad and heavy absorption in the whole UVâvis-NIR region between 200 nm and 2000 nm. With the introduction of Ag2S into CC composite, all of the ACC composites show intense absorption enhancements in the UVâvis range, and their Photo-absorption edges are extended to NIR region in comparison with the CC composite successfully. As a result, this strong and wide light absorption of ACC composites will possess tremendous photocatalytic latent force under full spectrum of sunlight illumination, which gives ACC composites powerful ability to take full advantage of solar energy.

In older to confirm the rewarding effectiveness of Cd2SO4(OH)2 and Ag2S on the enhanced photocatalytic capability of CdS, the HER under irradiation of UV (Fig. 3 a), Vis (Fig. 3b), NIR (Fig. 3c) and simulated sunlight (Fig. 3d) have been investigated. Predictably, after the intimate coupling of CdS and Cd2SO4(OH)2, CC composite exhibits greatly enhanced HER (51.3 Î¼mol/h under UV light, 17.9 Î¼mol/h under Vis light and 7.8 Î¼mol/h under simulated sunlight) compared to pure CdS (36.6 Î¼mol/h under UV light, 7.3 Î¼mol/h under Vis light and 5.2 Î¼mol/h under simulated sunlight). Meanwhile, the HER of the physical mixture of Cd2SO4(OH)2 and CdS with different mass ratios is shown in Fig. S4. It can be drawn that the H2 output of the Cd2SO4(OH)2-CdS physical mixture (the mass ratio is less than 3:5) is further improved compared with pure CdS and Cd2SO4(OH)2, indicating the introduction of Cd2SO4(OH)2 can efficiently promote the photocatalytic capability of CdS. Significantly, CC composite shows more excellent photocatalytic H2 evolution activity than Cd2SO4(OH)2-CdS physical mixture, attributing to the constitution of a more effective heterojunction between Cd2SO4(OH)2 and CdS by one-step hydrothermal method. However, the CC composite shows negligible H2 evolution capacity under NIR light irradiation, which could be restrained by their wide band gap. Fortunately, after the introduction of Ag2S on the CC composite surface, all ACC composites exhibit intense photocatalytic activity enhancement no matter under which kind of light irradiation compared with CC composite. Remarkably, the photocatalytic activities of ACC composites are highly dependent on the Ag2S content. When small amount (2â7 wt%) of Ag2S is introduced in the ACC system, 2ACC, 5ACC and 7ACC show stepwise growth of the photocatalytic activity, and the 7ACC composite reaches the best H2 production capacity under various light illumination (179.2 Î¼mol/h under UV light, 106.9 Î¼mol/h under Vis light 0.3 Î¼mol/h under NIR light and 35.6 Î¼mol/h under simulated sunlight). However, the further increase of Ag2S amount (10 wt%, 20 wt%) leads to the restraint of photocatalytic H2 production activity. For further investigation on this appearance, the surface states of series of ACC composites are observed by SEM, as shown in Fig. S3d-h. It can be found that with the amount of Ag2S deposition increases, the Ag2S particles on the surface of CC microsphere gradually agglomerate into large clusters instead of tiny and evenly distributed particles. It is rational since that the large-scale Ag2S aggregate clusters will not only shield active sites on the CC microsphere surface and obstruct the absorption of incident light, but also act as the new charge carrier recombination center to deteriorate the photocatalytic performance [30]. In addition, BET measurements are employed to assess the specific surface area of photocatalysts considering the influence of Ag2S loading on the surface of CC microspheres, and the HER per unit gram and per unit surface area are calculated under four kinds of light illumination to explore the impression of specific surface area on the photocatalytic activity of samples (Table S3, Fig. S5). All the above data show that HER per unit surface area of samples shows a similar change trend with HER per unit gram. It is confirmed that the promotion of photocatalytic performance is not only due to the increase of specific surface area caused by Ag2S loading, but more importantly, it is attributed to the formation of heterostructure between Ag2S and CdS, which is conducive for the charge separation and migration efficiency in the photocatalytic hydrogen production process. All in all, it can be concluded that loading Ag2S particles on the CC composite can successfully improve the carrier efficiency as well as sunlight utilization rate of ACC composites at the same time and enhance its photocatalytic performance under the full-spectrum sunlight irradiation effectively.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Apparent quantum yield (AQY) and Solar to hydrogen (STH) efficiency
ce:section.ce:para: Moreover, the wavelength-dependent H2 production AQY of 7ACC has been explored (Fig. S6a, Table S2). It is found that the AQY of 7ACC composite continually reduces with the increase of the incident light wavelength, which is found to track the characteristic absorption of the 7ACC composite, indicating the H2 production process of 7ACC composite is mainly rely on the photogenerated carriers in Ag2S/CdS/Cd2SO4(OH)2 heterostructures [37]. Notably, the AQY of 7ACC composite gets to the maximum of 4.46 % at 420 nm, and still exists at 850 nm, which further proves the high-efficiency full-solar-spectral photocatalytic activity of Ag2S/CdS/Cd2SO4(OH)2 photocatalytic system. Furthermore, it is reported that the hydrogen output is not necessarily proportional to the mass of photocatalyst, owing to the restriction of diffusion conditions and light absorption [38,39]. Hence, in order to explore the practical application potential of our photocatalytic system, and to facilitate the reasonable comparison with other photocatalytic systems in the future, the relationship of the AQY on the photocatalyst concentration is plotted (see Experimental Section). It can be obviously seen from Fig. S6b and Table S4 that the AQY (at 420 nm) of 7ACC composite increased with the raise of photocatalyst concentration, and it reaches the maximum value (5.77 %) at 1.0 g / L. Meanwhile, with the further increase of photocatalyst concentration, AQY decreased significantly, which proves that the light scattering caused by excessive photocatalyst will significantly reduce the practical application efficiency of photocatalyst [39]. It is believed that the Solar to hydrogen (STH) efficiency of photocatalyst is another important index reflecting the practical application potential of photocatalytic systems. Therefore, the STH efficiency of photocatalyst in our laboratory system is calculated by measuring HER of photocatalysts under simulated sunlight. Similar to the measurement of AQY, the efficiency of STH is further optimized by controlling the concentration of photocatalyst, and the pure CdS and 7ACC photocatalyst shows the maximum HER at 1.0 g / L and 1.2 g / L, respectively (Fig. S6c-d, Table S5). After calculation, the STH efficiency of 7ACC composite (0.24 %) exhibits an order of magnitude higher than that of bare CdS (0.03 %), indicating the formation of Ag2S/CdS/Cd2SO4(OH)2 can greatly improve the photocatalytic application potential of pure CdS.

It is well known that the photogenerated charge carrier dynamics has great impact on the photocatalytic performances, and the photocurrent measurement is one of the most useful methods to evaluate the separation and migration efficiency of the charge carriers [40]. Therefore, in order to further demonstrate the positive effect of the Cd2SO4(OH)2 and Ag2S on the improved photocatalytic activities, the photocurrent properties of pure CdS, Cd2SO4(OH)2, Ag2S, CC composite and 7ACC composite are tested under the selective conditions, as indicated in Fig. 3eâh. Clearly, the combination of CdS and Cd2SO4(OH)2 promotes their respective photocurrent response under the irradiation of UV and Vis light, and the photocurrent density has been further improved after the introduction of Ag2S into CC composite (Fig. 3e and f). Specifically, the photocurrent density of 7ACC composite reaches 53.0 Î¼A/cm2 under UV light and 21.4 Î¼A/cm2 under Vis light, which is about 3 times and 2 times than that of CC composite, respectively. As discussed before, the pure CdS, Cd2SO4(OH)2 and CC composite almost have no response to NIR light owing to their wide band gap, and the Ag2S also exhibits extremely weak photocurrent intensity because of its low charge carrier separation efficiency (Fig. 3g). However, after the deposition of Ag2S onto the surface of CC composite, the photocurrent intensity of 7ACC composite (1.85 Î¼A/cm2) show a significant promotion under the NIR light irradiation. As expected, 7ACC composite still shows the highest photocurrent intensity under the irradiation of simulated sunlight, and the photocurrent decreases with the order of 7ACC (9.2 Î¼A/cm2)> CC (3.7 Î¼A/cm2)> CdS (3.1 Î¼A/cm2)> Ag2S (0.5 Î¼A/cm2)> Cd2SO4(OH)2 (nearly no response). Therefore, it can be concluded from the above results that the combination of CdS and Cd2SO4(OH)2, and the further introduction of Ag2S onto the CC composite surface will greatly boost the separation and migration of the photoinduced electron-hole pairs inside CdS photocatalyst, which extremely enhances the HER of CdS under full spectrum light illumination.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Photocatalytic stability and performance of Ag2S/CdS/Cd system
ce:section.ce:para: It is reported that the photocorrosion of CdS photocatalysts during the photocatalytic H2 production processes has greatly inhibited their cyclic performances and large-scale applications [41]. To explore the helpful effectiveness of the introduction of Cd2SO4(OH)2 and Ag2S on the increased photostability, 6 cyclic photocatalytic H2 production has been performed for CdS, CC and 7ACC composites under the same conditions (see Experimental Section), and the corresponding results are displayed in Fig. 4 a. It can be found that the photocatalytic efficiency of CdS decreased to some extent (the H2 evolution efficiency of CdS fell by 23.5 % after 6 cycles), indicating the severe photocorrosion of pure CdS particles in photocatalytic process. On the contrary, it is amazing that the photocatalytic activity of CC and 7ACC composites are significantly improved rather than decreased within 3 cycles, and the H2 evolution efficiency of CC and 7ACC increased by 44.1 % and 39.7 % respectively. To clarify the above abnormal phenomenon, the XRD is employed to prove the presence of Cd metal in CC-2nd and 7ACC-2nd samples (CC and 7ACC samples after 2nd cyclic reaction under simulated sunlight illumination). As shown in Fig. 4b, the XRD spectra of the fresh and used CC and 7ACC composites clearly exhibit that the Cd2SO4(OH)2 phase has disappeared after 2 cycles photocatalytic H2 production process, following the generation of Cd metal (PDF 05-0674) characteristic peaks at 31.8 Â°, 34.7 Â° and 38.4 Â°. Meanwhile, it can be obviously seen from the HRTEM diagram of CC-2nd sample that Cd metal particles fix on the CdS surface (Fig. 4c) and the lattice spacing of 0.234 nm could also be assigned to the (101) plane of Cd metal (Fig. 4d). Furthermore, the EDX elemental line diagram shows that S signal attenuated continuously after approaching the CdS/Cd metal interface, while Cd signal intensity does not change significantly, which further proves formation of Cd metal clusters on the CdS surface (Fig. 4e). It is worth noting that S signal does not disappear rapidly after passing through CdS/Cd metal interface, confirming the tight coupling between CdS and Cd metal. Moreover, it can be found from the EDX spectra of CC and CC-2nd samples that the peak of O disappears significantly after 2 cycles, which also proves the disappearance of Cd2SO4(OH)2 phase (Fig. S7c-d). Besides that, the high-resolution XPS spectra of Cd 3d in 7ACC composite after the 2nd photocatalytic H2 production cycles are detected respectively. As shown in Fig. S7a, the original peaks which correspond to Cd atom in the CdOH (405.3 eV and 412.1 eV) disappear after the 2nd cyclic photocatalytic process, while the peaks correspond to Cd atom in the Cd-S bond (405.0 eV and 411.8 eV) decrease slightly and a new couple of peaks which could be indexed to CdÂ° gradually arise at 404.7 eV and 411.5 eV [42]. Combining the above results, it is realistic to conclude that during the photocatalytic processes, the Cd2+ in Cd2SO4(OH)2 are in-situ reduced to the Cd metal clusters and intimately fixed on the CdS surface by the photoinduced electrons, and the in-situ-formed Cd metal is the key to produce this peculiar photocatalytic phenomenon. To further demonstrate the beneficial effectiveness of the Cd metal cluster during photocatalytic processes, a set of experiments are implemented. Firstly, the photocatalytic properties of 7ACC-2nd sample are measured and shown in Fig. 4 fâg and Table S6. As expected, not only the HER (242.4 Î¼mol/h under UV light, 157.7 Î¼mol/h under Vis light 0.45 Î¼mol/h under NIR light and 49.7 Î¼mol/h under simulated sunlight), but also the AQY (7.60 % at 420 nm) and STH (0.35 %) of 7ACC-2nd sample under the optimal conditions show a certain improvement in comparison to 7ACC sample (the experimental system to see Experimental Section), indicating the presence of Cd metal can significantly enhance the photocatalytic activity under full spectrum of sunlight. Meanwhile, the wavelength-dependent H2 production AQY of 7ACC-2nd sample is also has been detected (Fig. 4h, Table S7), and the AQY of 7ACC-2nd has been observed to track the characteristic absorption of 7acc-2nd. It is proved that the H2 production process of 7acc-2nd is mainly dependent on the photogenerated carriers in the new system (Ag2S/CdS/Cd). To explore mass balance between oxidation of sacrificial reagents and hydrogen evolution, the ion concentration in the solution after hydrogen production reaction (7ACC-2nd sample under simulated sunlight for 4 h) was measured (Table S8). The results show that the stoichiometric molar ratio of hole number (0.3976 mmol) consumed by sacrificial agent oxidation reaction to electron number (0.3448 mmol) consumed by hydrogen production reaction is close to 1:1, indicating that the use of Na2S and Na2SO3 as sacrificial reagents can largely avoid the side reaction of the Ag2S/CdS/Cd system during the photocatalytic process. After that, the photocurrent responses of fresh CC, 7ACC samples and CC-2nd, 7ACC-2nd samples are employed under different light irradiation. It can be observed in Fig. 4iâl that both of CC-2nd and 7ACC-2nd samples display much higher photocurrent intensities than CC and 7ACC samples no matter on the irradiation of UV, Vis and simulated sunlight. Meanwhile, under the NIR light illumination, the 7ACC-2nd sample shows a significant improvement in photocurrent intensity compared with the 7ACC sample, while the CC and CC-2nd samples still exhibit nearly no response to the NIR light. The above results demonstrate that the Cd metal on the surface of CdS can establish a new electron transfer channel inside Ag2S/CdS/Cd heterostructures to promote the charge carriers transfer efficiency among Ag2S, CdS and Cd metal. Meanwhile, the formation of Schottky junction between CdS and Cd metal further inhibits the backflow of the photogenerated electrons from Cd metal to CdS [43], which promotes the photogenerated electron-hole pairs spatial separation efficiency of the 7ACC composite greatly, provide much more electrons for photocatalytic H2 production.

However, the hydrogen production of CC composite in the 6th cycle is only 69.7 % of that in the 3rd cycle, which shows a stronger photocorrosion than pure CdS. This is due to the formation of Cd metal can effectively capture the photogenerated electrons in CdS, while make a mass of holes remain in CdS, which aggravates the photocorrosion of CdS in the CC composite. It is remarkable that the HER of 7ACC composite is still 1.13 times higher than that of fresh 7ACC composite after 6 cycles, attributing to the introducing of Ag2S can accept the photoinduced holes in CdS and weaken the photocorrosion of CdS. Even so, the deactivation can also be observed in each H2 production cycle after the 3rd cycle, and the decay rate decreases with the increase of the cycle index. The high-resolution XPS spectra of Ag 3d are employed to explain this phenomenon (Fig. S7b), it can be seen that except the inherent Ag+ peaks of Ag2S location at 367.6 eV and 373.6 eV, two little peaks related to the Ag metal can be observed at 368.5 eV and 374.5 eV in 7ACC composite after the 2nd cyclic reaction runs [44], and the gradual deactivation of Ag2S caused by the production of metal Ag is the primary cause for the reduced photocatalytic activity. Meanwhile, a certain amount of metal Ag accumulation will capture the residual electrons in Ag2S, which makes the photocatalytic activity gradually stable [20]. Beyond that, the comparisons of HER properties of photocatalysts in this work and other CdS-based photocatalysts are revealed in Table S9. As expected, compared to many other CdS-based photocatalysts, both 7ACC photocatalyst and 7ACC-2nd photocatalyst exhibit higher photocatalytic activity and better enhancements of pure CdS photocatalyst, which proves that the construction of Ag2S/CdS/Cd2SO4(OH)2 and Ag2S/CdS/Cd carrier spatial separation system can efficiently extend the optical absorption region of pure CdS as well as greatly improve its carrier utilization.

In order to comprehend the transfer processes of photoinduced electron-hole pairs between Ag2S/CdS/Cd2SO4(OH)2 and Ag2S/CdS/Cd interface during the UVâvis-NIR light-induced H2 production, the energy level alignment and interfacial band bending of Ag2S/CdS/Cd2SO4(OH)2 system are first discussed [45]. The bands edge positions of Ag2S/CdS/Cd2SO4(OH)2 heterostructure is determined by the combined information from UPS spectra and UVâvis-NIR absorption spectra (Fig. S8 aâf). It is reported that EVB could be calculated by subtracting the width of the He I UPS spectra from the excitation energy (21.22 eV) [46,47], which are calculated to be 1.86 eV vs NHE (21.22-(20.32â5.40) = 6.30 eV vs Evac) for CdS [48,49]. Considering the bandgap energy (2.34 eV for CdS) obtained, the conduction band (ECB) of CdS is at -0.48 eV vs NHE (2.34 eV-1.86 eV), from EVB â Eg. Similarly, following this process, the ECB and EVB of Cd2SO4(OH)2 (-0.43 eV vs NHE and 3.97 eV vs NHE) and Ag2S (-0.56 eV vs NHE and 0.39 eV vs NHE) are obtained separately [27,50]. Meanwhile, it is believed that the flat band potential reflects the differences between the water-reduction potential and Fermi levels of semiconductors [51,52], so the Fermi level values are calculated from the flat band energies of the Mott â Schottky plots (Fig. S9g-i). After calculation, the Fermi level positions of CdS, Cd2SO4(OH)2 and Ag2S are -0.264 eV vs NHE (-0.461 eV vs Ag/AgCl +0.197 eV), -0.342 eV vs NHE (-0.539 eV vs Ag/AgCl +0.197 eV) and -0.156 eV vs NHE (-0.353 eV vs Ag/AgCl +0.197 eV), respectively. Hence, the energy level alignment of the Ag2S/CdS/Cd2SO4(OH)2 heterostructure has been obtained and illustrated Fig. S9. Based on the above data, the band bending direction and carrier transfer mode between Ag2S, CdS and Cd2SO4(OH)2 can be determined. when a heterojunction is formed between Ag2S and CdS, electrons will be transferred from CdS with high Fermi level to Ag2S with low Fermi level until their Fermi level positions are aligned. After that, depletion layers (positive charge region) and accumulation layers (negative charge region) are generated on the Cd2SO4(OH)2 and CdS sides of the interface respectively, resulting in the energy band edge of CdS is bent downward toward the interface, while that of Cd2SO4(OH)2 is bent upward toward the interface (Fig. 5 a). Similarly, there is the same band bending mode at the interface of CdS and Ag2S, as shown in Fig. 5b. Hence, the photogenerated electrons in CdS (Ag2S) can move into Cd2SO4(OH)2 (CdS) smoothly whereas the holes in Cd2SO4(OH)2 (CdS) can flow into CdS (Ag2S) freely, indicating the typical charge transfer path of type-II heterojunction at the two interface (Fig. 5). As described above, electrons in CdS will flow into Cd2SO4(OH)2 during the H2 production process, resulting in the production of metal Cd to form a final Ag2S/CdS/Cd system. In order to intuitively explore the carrier transport pathway of the Ag2S/CdS/Cd system, the photodeposition Au on the Ag2S/CdS and CdS/Cd (CC-2nd) sample has been investigated [53,54]. As shown in Fig. S10a-b, Au particles are largely deposited on CdS for Ag2S/CdS sample, while there is no obvious Au particle deposition on Ag2S, indicating photoinduced electron will transfer from Ag2S to CdS. Similarly, the presence of Au particle can be observed only on the Cd metal surface (Fig. S10c-d) in the CdS/Cd (CC-2nd) sample, which proves the electrons will flow from CdS into metal Cd. As a consequence, the carriers in the new system are spatially separated at the two sites of Ag2S and metal Cd, which greatly improves photocatalytic activities ultimately.

Based on the above datum, the photocatalytic mechanism of the Ag2S/CdS/Cd2SO4(OH)2 system is proposed and illustrated in Fig. 6 . When Ag2S/CdS/Cd2SO4(OH)2 system is illustrated by UV or Vis light, either CdS or Ag2S could be excited to generate photoinduced electron-hole pairs. As mentioned above, only Ag2S can be excited under NIR light irradiation. Affected by the type-II heterojunction charge transfer pathway between CdS and Ag2S, the photogenerated electrons and holes will be transferred from CB of Ag2S to CB of CdS and from VB of CdS to VB of Ag2S, respectively and then the photogenerated electrons in the CB of CdS could be transferred to the lower CB of Cd2SO4(OH)2. Meanwhile, under the disparity between the reduction potential of Cd2+/CdÂ° (-0.40 eV vs. NHE) and CB potential of Cd2SO4(OH)2 (-0.43 eV vs. NHE) [55], the Cd2+ in Cd2SO4(OH)2 will be in-situ reduced into CdÂ° (Eq. (4)), and then the in-situ-formed Cd metal could be tightly fixed on the CdS surface and act as a superior electron trap to receive electrons in the CdS. In this process, Cd metal and Ag2S are used as reaction sites for photocatalytic hydrogen production and reaction with sacrificial agent respectively, which successfully realized the spatial effective separation of photogenerated carriers and significantly improved the activity of hydrogen evolution. In terms of reaction kinetics, the Ag2S/CdS/Cd system provides spatially separated photocatalytic redox sites, which is a desirable photocatalytic system for hydrogen production.

In summary, a noble-metal-free CdS/Cd2SO4(OH)2 composite has been successfully designed and prepared via a convenient one-step solvothermal method. It can be identified that Cd2SO4(OH)2 could be gradually in-situ reduced to Cd metal by the photoinduced electrons injected from CdS, and the in-situ-formed Cd metal serves on a superior electron trap as well as offer a great deal of hydrogen production sites. This method has not only realized an effective contact between CdS and Cd metal, but also avoided the loss of pure CdS due to photocorrosion in the process of photochemical deposition. Moreover, after the introduction of Ag2S with the wide spectrum absorption property onto the surface of CdS, the hybridization system shows a full-spectrum-responsive photocatalytic capacity for high-efficiency hydrogen evolution. As a result, the final Ag2S/CdS/Cd system exhibits an excellent photocatalytic performance for hydrogen production no matter on the illumination of UV, Vis or NIR light. The final analyzed results have presented an offer corresponding to a new inspiration to develop a low-cost and carrier spatial separation photocatalytic hydrogen evolution system to evaluate full superiorities of solar energy in trap future. Importantly, this study is expected to display a new approach for in-situ deposition of metal clusters on the photocatalyst surface during the photocatalytic process.
